item.title: Why Rising Israel-Iran Tensions Threaten to Boil Over
item.description: The conflict between Israel and Iran has shaped the Middle East for decades. It was largely on a low boil as the two sides attacked each other — mostly quietly and in Iran’s case often by proxy — while avoiding a full-blown war.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Sykes, Ethan Bronner, Anthony Capaccio

media:content.media:description: An anti-Israel billboard in Tehran, on May 5.

item.title: EU Unveils Plan to Revitalize World’s Second-Biggest Market
item.description: The European Union is seeking to strengthen its common market in the face of rising geopolitical tensions and a growing trade conflict with the US, which is threatening to hit the bloc with wide-ranging tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Crook, Michal Kubala, Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: European Commission President Ursula Von der Leyen on May 21.

item.title: US Deportation Plan Under Scrutiny Amid South Sudan Confusion
item.description: The US Department of Homeland Security said eight immigrants convicted of serious crimes remain in federal custody following a deportation attempt that sparked confusion over whether they were sent to South Sudan, a country gripped by years of violence.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JUNE 6: An ICE agent monitors hundreds of asylum seekers being processed upon entering the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building on June 6, 2023 in New York City. New York City has provided sanctuary to over 46,000 asylum seekers since 2013, when the city passed a law prohibiting city agencies from cooperating with federal immigration enforcement agencies unless there is a warrant for the person's arrest.(Photo by David Dee Delgado/Getty Images) Photographer: David Dee Delgado/Getty Images North America

item.title: Trump Says Tax Bill ‘Close’ as GOP Holdouts Threaten to Sink It
item.description: President Donald Trump’s said his massive tax package is close to being finalized, having notched a deal over the state and local tax deduction, but the White House has yet to win over a faction of conservatives who want more austere spending cuts.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Andy Harris

item.title: Starmer U-Turns on Signature Benefit Cut That Backfired
item.description: Britain’s Labour government will make its sharpest U-turn since returning to power by limiting cuts to pensioners’ subsidies, as it puts the electoral threat posed by Nigel Farage ahead of lingering concern about the public finances.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White, Philip Aldrick, Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer

item.title: Tax Bill to Accelerate Medicaid Work Requirements to 2026
item.description: House Republicans leaders are planning to accelerate new Medicaid work requirements to December 2026 in a deal with ultra-conservatives on the giant tax bill, according to a lawmaker familiar with the discussions.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Rachel Cohrs Zhang

media:content.media:description: Medical equipment is seen in a procedure room at a clinic in San Antonio, Texas.

item.title: Romanian Leader Says Minority Coalition May Need to Push Reforms
item.description: Romania’s interim president said a government lacking a parliamentary majority may need to push through urgent reforms if parties don’t set aside differences and forge a broader pro-European coalition.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu

media:content.media:description: Ilie Bolojan Photographer: Daniel Mihailescu/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: South Africa’s Third Budget Wins Support, Easing Political Risk
item.description: South Africa’s finance minister calmed a months-long political crisis that had threatened the stability of its governing coalition, presenting a fiscally careful budget that won support from lawmakers and investors.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana

item.title: DOGE Asks US Supreme Court to Block Access to Its Records
item.description: The Trump administration has asked the US Supreme Court to halt a judge’s order that would force it to answer questions from a watchdog group and turn over documents about Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency in a fight over public access to the office’s records.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC

item.title: Murders in Quiet Neighborhood Shatter Mexico City’s Calm
item.description: In the vast swaths of Mexico controlled by drug cartels, public executions and mass graves have long been the norm. Mexico City has largely been a haven from the goriest headlines.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Navarro, Maya Averbuch, Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Forensic investigators at the crime scene in Mexico city on May 20.

item.title: Milei Stumbles in Bid to Unchain Farmers as Soy Tax Break Ends
item.description: President Javier Milei’s vow to unleash Argentina’s beleaguered farmers is faltering after a decision to raise taxes on soy exports by about seven percentage points.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Gilbert

media:content.media:description: A combine harvester cuts through a field of soybean plants in San Jose de la Esquina, Argentina.

item.title: Tanzania Curbs Internet After X Posts Fake President’s Death
item.description: Tanzania restricted internet access after several government accounts on the X social network platform were compromised.
item.dc:creator: Fumbuka Ng'Wanakilala

media:content.media:description: Samia Suluhu Hassan, president of Tanzania.

item.title: Space Startup Iceye Boosts Poland Investment to Meet Army Demand
item.description: Iceye Oy, the Finnish maker of advanced Earth-observation satellites, plans further investments in Poland as it sees increased demand from countries that want to improve their intelligence-gathering capabilities in space.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski

media:content.media:description: A depiction of Iceye’s SAR satellites.

item.title: Israel Fired Warning Shots at EU, China Diplomats by Mistake
item.description: Israeli soldiers mistakenly fired warning shots at diplomats representing the European Union, UK, China, Russia and other countries on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Fadwa Hodali, Alisa Odenheimer

media:content.media:description: Israeli army armoured vehicles enter Jenin during a military operation on May 21.

item.title: Meloni Looks to Moody’s to End Italy’s Near-Junk Status
item.description: Italy is just two days away from the chance to start shaking off the near-junk status that has hung over Giorgia Meloni’s premiership.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio

media:content.media:description: Giorgia Meloni Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

item.title: Johnson Says Deal Reached on Raising SALT Cap to $40,000
item.description: House Speaker Mike Johnson said Republicans have reached an agreement to increase the state and local tax deduction to $40,000, suggesting a resolution to one of the final issues holding up President Donald Trump’s economic bill.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Nacha Cattan

media:content.media:description: House Speaker Mike Johnson

item.title: GOP Senators Scrutinize Proxy Advisers Over Potential Conflicts
item.description: Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee are probing two top proxy advisory firms over potential political bias and conflicts of interest, in a renewed push to subject the industry to greater oversight.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Beyoud

media:content.media:description: Senator Tim Scott, a Republican from South Carolina and ranking member of the Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee, speaks during a hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Dec. 11, 2024. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is working on a rule that would allow domestic violence and elder abuse victims to expunge "coerced debt" from their credit reports.

item.title: EU Prepares New Trade Proposal in Bid to Reach Deal With US
item.description: The European Union was expected to share a revised trade proposal with the US, as it aims to inject momentum in talks with President Donald Trump’s administration amid lingering skepticism that a transatlantic deal can be reached.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Stacked shipping containers at Hamburg Port. Photographer: Sean Gallup/Getty Images

item.title: Kremlin Vows to Defend Its Ships in the Baltic by All Legal Ways
item.description: Russia will defend its vessels in the Baltic Sea by all legal means, the Kremlin said, days after briefly deploying a fighter jet as Estonian officials tried to halt a so-called shadow fleet tanker in their economic zone.
item.dc:creator: James Herron

media:content.media:description: The Kremlin in Moscow. Photographer: Natalia Kolesnikova/Getty Images

item.title: Trump Ramps Up Criminal Charges Against Migrants in California
item.description: The Trump administration is filing criminal charges against more immigrants in the US illegally as part of an effort to skirt state and city policies that limit local cooperation.
item.dc:creator: Alicia A. Caldwell, Myles Miller

media:content.media:description: US Border Patrol agents take asylum seekers into custody along the US-Mexico border near Jacumba Hot Springs, California.

item.title: Musk to Join Trump for Meeting With South Africa’s Ramaphosa
item.description: Elon Musk will join President Donald Trump’s meeting with South African leader Cyril Ramaphosa at the White House on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: S'thembile Cele, Loni Prinsloo

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump greets Elon Musk before a state dinner at the Lusail Palace in Doha, Qatar, on May 14.

item.title: Sputtering Iran-US Talks Revive Specter of Israeli Solo Strike
item.description: A US media outlet reports that Israel may be poised to strike Iran’s nuclear sites and oil markets wince. In Washington, a Republican administration wonders if Tehran is more determined or deterred.
item.dc:creator: Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: The Bushehr nuclear power plant in Iran. Photographer: Morteza Nikoubazl/NurPhoto/Getty Images

item.title: Behind Trump’s ‘Most Exclusive’ Dinner, a Partner Sells Access
item.description: A dinner on Thursday in Washington — billed as the “Most Exclusive Once in Lifetime Invitation” — is the latest and boldest spectacle Bill Zanker has launched for Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Olga Kharif

media:content.media:description: Bill Zanker, left, and Donald Trump during the “Think Big and Kick Ass” book signing at Barnes & Noble in New York in 2007.

item.title: Russian Advance in Ukraine Is Slowing Despite Putin’s Confidence
item.description: Russian forces in Ukraine have made only small territorial gains this year amid steady resistance from Kyiv’s military, undercutting President Vladimir Putin’s assertions that his army has gained the upper hand in the war.
item.dc:creator: Volodymyr Verbianyi, Aliaksandr Kudrytski

media:content.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier walks past damaged buildings following combat with Russian troops in central Pokrovsk, Donetsk region, on April 23. Photographer: Michael Shtekel/AP Photo

item.title: Swedish Ministers Face Pressure Over Undeclared Shareholdings
item.description: Sweden’s government faces a political backlash after several ministers were found to own stock in sectors they decide on, further tarnishing the Nordic image of low corruption after a similar scandal in neighboring Norway.
item.dc:creator: Jonas Ekblom

media:content.media:description: Maria Malmer Stenergard Photographer: Nicolas Tucat/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Winners and Losers in South Africa’s Latest Budget Attempt
item.description: South African Finance Minister Enoch Godongwana presented a third version of the national budget to lawmakers in Cape Town on Wednesday after months of wrangling over tax increases.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cohen

media:content.media:description: Street vendors at an outdoor market in Pretoria, South Africa. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: Highlights of South African Finance Minister’s Reworked Budget
item.description: Below are the highlights of South Africa’s third iteration of the 2025 budget announced by Finance Minister Enoch Godongwana in Cape Town on Wednesday, after two previous versions were withdrawn because of disagreements within the governing coalition over taxes.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek

media:content.media:description: Over the next three years, 1.03 trillion rand will be allocated to public infrastructure. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: Mnuchin Flags US Budget Deficit as Bigger Worry Than Trade Gap
item.description: Former United States Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said he’s more alarmed by the country’s growing budget deficit than its trade imbalances, and urged Washington to prioritize fiscal repair.
item.dc:creator: Anto Antony

media:content.media:description: Steven Mnuchin Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Jr. Says ‘Maybe One Day’ He’ll Look to Succeed His Father
item.description: Donald Trump Jr. hinted that he may run for political office and try to succeed his father as US president.
item.dc:creator: Paul Wallace, Beril Akman, Zainab Fattah, Joumanna Bercetche

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump Jr. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

item.title: Nigerian Opposition Leaders Agree to Unite Before 2027 Election
item.description: Nigeria’s top opposition leaders agreed to unite before the next election in 2027, seeking to repair rifts that handed President Bola Tinubu victory in an election two years ago.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo

media:content.media:description: A supporter rides on the side of a minibus holding a Labour Party flag.
